verses.text: He who loves his son disciplines him often, that he may rejoice at his coming of age.
verses.comment: Discipline as an act of love runs throughout both Old and New Testaments. Good parents instruct and guide their children, reflecting the heavenly Father's correction of His people (see Prov. 3:12; Heb. 12:6-7).

verses.text: He who disciplines his son will profit by him, and will boast of him among his acquaintances.
verses.comment: The biblical model presents family as a school for virtue, preparing children for greater duties in the community and the worshipping assembly.

verses.text: Whoever teaches his son will make his enemies envious, and will rejoice in him among his friends.
verses.comment: Virtuous children reflect their parents' wisdom before others, causing even opponents to admire and respect their upbringing.

verses.text: When his father dies, it is as though he is not dead, for he has left behind one like himself.
verses.comment: A well-instructed child continues his father's legacy, making family an enduring line of witness and faithfulness.

verses.text: In his lifetime he saw and rejoiced in him, and at his death he was not grieved.
verses.comment: The joy of seeing one’s child flourish provides consolation even at death—an encouragement to nurture children for more than material blessing.

verses.text: He leaves an avenger against his enemies, and one to repay kindness to his friends.
verses.comment: Loyalty to kin and friends is a mark of godly families, and provides spiritual security and earthly defenses.

verses.text: Whoever spoils his son will have to bind up his wounds, and his heart will tremble at every cry.
verses.comment: Overindulgence leads to sorrow and worry, reminding parents to raise children with loving discipline and clear expectations.

verses.text: A horse that is unbroken turns out stubborn, and a child left to himself becomes willful.
verses.comment: Just as discipline tames and guides, so spiritual formation is necessary—not merely external order but inward transformation.

verses.text: Pamper a child, and he will terrify you; play with him, and he will bring you grief.
verses.comment: A warning against neglecting one’s responsibilities—true love does not shrink from correction.

verses.text: Do not laugh with him, lest you be forced to mourn, and in the end your teeth be set on edge.
verses.comment: Balanced affection is called for; too much lenience produces future sorrow.

verses.text: Give him no authority in his youth, and do not overlook his faults.
verses.comment: Parents carry God-given authority—a pattern mirrored in church life, where leaders are to shepherd with both firmness and gentleness.

verses.text: Bow down his neck in his youth, and beat his sides while he is a child, lest he become stubborn and disobey you.
verses.comment: This reflects the ancient practice of corporal discipline. In the broader sense, spiritual discipline is necessary for growth in faith and character.

verses.text: Discipline your son, and make his yoke heavy, lest you be offended by his behavior and sorely grieved.
verses.comment: Raising a child well is not easy, but the long-term fruit is peace and honor—echoing the biblical call to perseverance in doing good.

verses.text: Better a poor man who is healthy and strong, than a rich man with disease in his bones.
verses.comment: True wealth is found in health and virtue, not in fleeting riches—pointing to Jesus’ teaching to store up treasures in heaven.

verses.text: Health and good constitution are better than all gold, and a strong body is worth more than great wealth.
verses.comment: Physical prowess is inferior only to spiritual well-being; here, the focus is on holistic human flourishing.

verses.text: No riches can compare with health of body, and there is no happiness above joy of heart.
verses.comment: Spiritual and emotional gladness surpass all that the world offers—anticipating Christ’s promise of abundant life (John 10:10).

verses.text: Death is better than a miserable life, and eternal rest than unceasing sickness.
verses.comment: For the faithful, even death is seen as a release into the hope of eternal life—a theme echoed by Paul and fulfilled in Christ’s resurrection.

verses.text: Good things set before a person who cannot eat are as useless as offerings laid upon a tomb.
verses.comment: All material blessings are wasted if one cannot enjoy them, a symbol for the deeper truth that true sufficiency is found in God.

verses.text: What good is a sacrifice to an idol? It cannot be eaten. So are the offerings to the dead.
verses.comment: The text stresses the futility of rituals that lack true purpose—echoing the biblical call to worship the living God in spirit and truth (John 4:24).

verses.text: He looks at food and sighs, like a eunuch embracing a virgin.
verses.comment: This image highlights the pain of unfulfilled desire, a reminder that satisfaction apart from God and purpose is vain.

verses.text: Do not give yourself over to sorrow, nor afflict yourself deliberately.
verses.comment: The Bible exhorts believers to place hope in God and practice joy even in tribulation (Rom. 5:3-5, Phil. 4:4).

verses.text: The joy of the heart is life to a man, and cheerfulness prolongs his days.
verses.comment: Inner gladness is a spiritual gift, sustaining body and soul—an early pointer to the fruit of the Spirit (Gal. 5:22).

verses.text: Delight your soul, and comfort your heart. Keep sorrow far from you; for sorrow has destroyed many, and there is no profit in it.
verses.comment: Joy and encouragement are part of God’s remedy for the afflicted. The cultivation of inner peace is an important biblical discipline.

verses.text: Envy and anger shorten one’s life, worry brings old age before its time.
verses.comment: Emotional health is linked with physical well-being—a holistic view of personhood echoed in Scriptural teaching on forgiveness and reconciliation.

verses.text: A cheerful and good heart is concerned with food, but he who cannot eat will be hard to comfort.
verses.comment: Joy and sorrow affect even daily necessities. The passage invites the faithful to seek the joy that comes from God alone—ultimately fulfilled in Christ, the Bread of Life (John 6:35).
